meaning_mnemonic: This looks just like a folding <radical>stool</radical>, am I right?

This radical looks just like the katakana character "ra" („É©). The sound "ra" sounds just like the famous Egyptian God "Ra" as well, so we're going to say this radical represents Egypt's God <radical>Ra</radical>.

This looks like a little whiteboard to keep track of your <radical>task</radical>s for the day. It's got three little legs on the bottom. And see those blank squares? meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>task</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>task</kanji> as well.

examples.en: Are you American?

meaning_mnemonic: The „Ç¢„É°„É™„Ç´ part is pretty easy so long as you know katakana. It's the word for "America." You know that <kanji>‰∫∫</kanji> means "person," so you can figure out that America + Person = <vocabulary>American person</vocabulary> ‚Äî specifically a <vocabulary>person from the USA</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Often times, when two kanji come together to form a kanji compound (or jukugo), you use the on'yomi readings. This is similar to that, though instead of another kanji it's a foreign word. This pattern works with almost any country as well. Just add ‰∫∫ to a country name and you've described the people who live there. You'll see more of these before you're finished here.

And since ‰∫∫ has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: 

<vocabulary>Americans</vocabulary> absolutely love their <reading>jean</reading>s („Åò„Çì), it's a well-known fact!

examples.en: Marbles are small, round balls.

examples.en: I'm planning to get a toy poodle that will be born this month.

examples.en: One draft beer, please.

meaning_mnemonic:
Normally a single kanji alone like this would mean the same thing as its parent kanji, but in the case of <kanji>Áîü</kanji> it's a little different (but still related). When you think of something that has life, it's <vocabulary>fresh</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>raw</vocabulary>. Think sashimi or sushi, for example. You want that to be as close as possible to life as you can, so you eat it when it's fresh and raw. This word can also be used to describe a <vocabulary>live</vocabulary> event, like a concert or sporting event. 

You'll see this word at the beginning of other words. For example, Áîü„Åü„Åæ„Åî is "raw egg."

examples.en: I'm in Japan right now.
